titlestmt.title: Blake's Annotations to Thornton's The Lord's Prayer Copy 1 : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: XML file approx. 59 KB; 22 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 945 KB to 42.9 MB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries May 2025
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of Blake’s annotations to Dr. Robert John Thornton’s The Lord’s Prayer, 1827. With this work, the Archive inaugurates the “Annotated Works” sub-category within the Archive’s category of Manuscripts and Typographic Works. This category has long been the purview of the late Morris Eaves and his editorial assistants at the University of Rochester, now under the supervision of Marcie Woehl.
When we think of annotations, we might think of the kind we make ourselves: quick notes to capture a reaction or thought provoked by the text at hand. These remarks are often unfiltered and, as such, quite reflective of their annotator. Blake’s annotations are no different. He was a spirited and active reader; he underlined, he argued, he corrected, and he celebrated— frequently all in one work. It is through these varied expressions that we are given access to Blake’s personality, thoughts, and impressions throughout the time period from which we have his annotations, roughly 1788-1827. Though it is not known how many works Blake may have annotated in his lifetime, eleven annotated texts are extant, and two other sets of annotations exist separate from the original texts.
Dr. Robert John Thornton’s The Lord’s Prayer is both the last work known to be annotated by Blake and the final work published by Thornton, who died destitute in 1837. Thornton was the personal physician to John Linnell, Blake’s last patron and the person who probably introduced him to Blake around 1818. Thornton commissioned Blake to illustrate an “Imitation of Eclogue I” in his successful school text, The Pastorals of Virgil, 1821. Blake’s wood engravings were unorthodox, technically and visually, and Thornton had to be persuaded by Linnell and other eminent artists to accept them. The Lord’s Prayer, however, would prove to be just as, if not more, divisive than Blake’s unconventional wood engravings. Part new translation and part commentary, Thornton’s “translation” modified the original Greek text to align better with his own conception of the work. As such, when Linnell presented Blake with a copy of Thornton’s text—likely for the express purpose of being returned with annotations—Blake had much motivating him to write. Though the scorned wood engravings may have played a factor in the hostility of his annotations, the translated prayer and accompanying “Critical and Explanatory Notes” were likely themselves the chief provocations, as much of “Doctor Thorntons Tory Translation” (Object 10) was quite categorically opposed to Blake’s own worldview. “I look upon this as the Most Malignant & Artful attack upon the Kingdom of Jesus…”, Blake declares in his first comment, arcing his bold opening salvo down the right-hand margin of the title page and, from there on, his criticisms, corrections, and at times, truly rancorous satire (“Lawful Bread Bought with Lawful Money & a Lawful Heaven seen thro a Lawful Telescope….”) will continue to the final page, culminating in a full parody of Thornton’s Lord’s Prayer.
Though Blake left little ambiguity regarding his feelings towards Thornton’s pamphlet, his annotations are not without a different kind of uncertainty. Predominantly written in pencil and then written over in ink, the annotations written only in pencil (perhaps too unclear to ink?)—such as those on Objects 6 and 10, in particular—are exceedingly difficult to read and have posed a challenge to all scholars to date seeking to represent them. Rigorously transcribed to reflect every deletion, addition, and uncertain text, the diplomatic transcription provided here creates a new digital resource for those interested in working with Blake’s spirited, and at times near-illegible, writings.
In a letter to John Linnell, dated August 29, 1828, Samuel Palmer remarked that his father “would be very much amused by a sight of Mr. Blake’s annotations to Dr. T.s [sic] Lord’s Prayer” (Bentley, Records, 486), and, indeed, contemporary readers will find themselves in a similar state of amusement reading the annotations, which are very likely the last words Blake wrote on the subject of the Bible. Capturing his deeply-held views on religion, politics, and economics alike, we must join in echoing Blake’s concluding statement of his parody, either in matching irony or diverging sincerity: “for all this we Thank Dr Thornton” (Object 10).
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objtitle.title: Blake's Annotations to Thornton's *The Lord's Prayer*

objdescid.origination: Robert John Thornton author of the printed text
J. McGowan and Son printer of the letterpress text

imprint.title: The Lord's Prayer, Newly Translated from the Original Greek, with Critical and Explanatory Notes
imprint.publisher: Sherwood and Co., Cox, and Dr. Thornton

objdescid.compdate: 1827If the imprint date on the frontispiece is the actual date of publication, Blake would presumably have annotated the text between March 31, 1827 and his death on August 12, 1827.

objinfo.numberobj: 11Including the title page, there are eleven pages of Thornton’s text, plus a label on the front cover and a frontispiece. We have reproduced the eleven objects bearing annotations, which include the verso of the final leaf (which has no letterpress text) and the recto of the back paper wrapper.
objinfo.numberleaves: 6Thornton's complete work is printed on eight leaves.
objinfo.leafsize: 28.5 x 21.6 cm.There are slight variations in dimension between leaves.
objinfo.medium: pen and ink, pencilMost of the annotations in pencil were later written over in ink.
objinfo.binding: originally stitched through original blue wrappers but all leaves now loose

provenance.name: The Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens
provenance.note: Apparently given to John Linnell by 1828; sold by trustees of the Linnell estate at Christie's on March 15, 1918, lot 204 for £50.8s. to G.D. Smith on behalf of Henry E. Huntington for The Huntington Library.

repository.institution: The Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens

desc.objtitle:
Title Page ,
Object 2 (Bentley Title-page, Erdman Title Page)

objnote.p: Blake's inscription on this object starts at the top of the page and curves downward, following the right margin.

lg.l: I look upon this as a Most Malignant & Artful
attack upon the Kingdom of Jesus
By the Classical Learned thro through the Instrumentality of Dr Thornton
The Greek & Roman Classics is the Antichrist
I say Is & not Are as most expressive
& correct too

desc.objtitle:
Title Page: Verso ,
Object 3 (Bentley title-page verso, Erdman ii)

objnote.p: The majority of Blake's inscribed text on this object was originally written in pencil and later confirmed in black ink, save for a few exceptions. Lines 9 through 13 are written only in pencil with the exception of "x" on line 11, which is written only in black ink. Lines 14 and 15 are written only in black ink, and "Was Johnson hired to Pretend to Religious" on line 17 and the text on line 18 are both confirmed in brown ink rather than black.

lg.l: Christ & his
Apostles were
Illiterate
Men
Pilate &
Herod
were Learned.

l.note: Lines 9 through 13 may have been partially erased. Neither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1514) nor Erdman (667) include the penciled inscription in their transcription. This inscription is repeated on lines 14 and 15.

lg.l: x Socrates
x Socrates was The Savior.
The Beauty of the Bible is that the most Ignorant & Simple Minds
Understand it Best — Was Johnson hired to Pretend to Religious

l.hi: Terrors while he was an Infidel or how was it

objnote.p: Lines 15-17 are written vertically, starting in the lower right corner and following the right margin.

lg.l: Such things as these depend on the Fashion of the Age

In a book where all may Read &} are Equally Right & A curled bracket between the two columns of text in lines 2-4 suggests a connection between the adjacent lines.The ampersand after "Right" is not confirmed in pen; Erdman omits this ampersand (668).
In a book which all may Read &That Man who &c is equally so The Man that Bentley reads the first "That" in this line as "that" and "Read" as "read"(*Writings* volume 2, page 1514).
In a book that all may Read& the Man which

ΠΑΤΕΡ ἡμῶν ὁ ἐν τοῖς ȣpανοῖς, ἁγιασθήτω— In lines 5-8, Blake appears to have copied his text directly from the Greek New Testament. The inscription on this line roughly translates to "Our Father, who art in heaven".
τὸ ογομα σȣ. In lines 5-8, Blake appears to have copied his text directly from the Greek New Testament. The inscription on this line roughly translates to "hallowed be thy name".
,—'ελθέτὠ η Βασιλεία τȣγενηθήτω το' In lines 5-8, Blake appears to have copied his text directly from the Greek New Testament. The inscription on this line roughly translates to "thy kingdom come".
θέλημα' σȣ, In lines 5-8, Blake appears to have copied his text directly from the Greek New Testament. The inscription on this line roughly translates to "thy will".
It is the learned that Mouth & not the Vulgar
Lawful Bread Bought with Lawful Money & a Lawful Heaven seen
thro through a Lawful Telescope by means of Lawful Window Light
The Holy Ghost wh cannot be Taxed is Unlawful & Witchcraft.
Spirits are Lawful but not Ghosts especially Royal Gin is Lawful Spirit real
No Smuggling ^ British Spirit & Truth
Give us the Bread that is our due & Right by taking away Money or a Price or
Tax upon what is Common to all in thy Kingdom

objnote.p: Blake's inscription on this object is written in pencil only. The writing begins at the bottom of the page and extends vertically along the right margin. Both Bentley and Erdman read the text alongside the right margin as continuous with the text beginning at the bottom of the page.
Erdman makes significant alterations to the order of the transcribed text. See Erdman pages 668-669.

lg.l:
Jesus our Father who art in ^ Heavns Heavens
calld called by thy Name the Holy Ghost Thy Kingdom Erdman reads "Heavns" as "Heavens" and indicates that the "s" at the end of the word is an addition (668).

l.note: Bentley reads the mostly-illegible word above "God" on line 4 as "father" followed by an ampersand. He reads this phrase inline with the text on line 4 (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516). Erdman omits this mostly-illegible word from his transcription (668).

subst.add: nor thy Will done but Will who is the God

l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (668) read the text of our line 10 as a continuation of this line.
Bentley reads the deleted illegible word as "his" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516), while Erdman reads the word as "Beelzebub", with "his" as an additional conjectural reading (658).
Bentley reads "who is" as an insertion (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).
Bentley reads "the God of this World" as "& God of this World" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).

subst.add: away Money or Debt or Tax as

l.note: Bentley designates that "us" in "Give us This Eternal Day" is written over an illegible word (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516). Erdman conjecturally reads the illegible word overwritten by "us" as "me" (669).
Erdman conjecturally reads the illegible word overwritten by "our" as "my" (669).
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (669) conjecturally read the illegible word before "Bread" as "Ghostly".
Bentley reads "Bread" as "bread" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).
Bentley conjecturally reads the illegible text following "Bread" as "to be" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (668) read the illegible word before "away" as "take".
Bentley reads "Debt" as "debt" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).
Bentley reads "a value or price" as "& value or price" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).
Erdman reads the illegible text after "as" as "we" (669).

Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (669) read "Satan Kingdom" as "Satans Kingdom"; additionally, Erdman conjectures that the text he reads as "Satans Kingdom" is written over "but deliver" (669).
Bentley reads the deleted illegible word at the end of this line as "Satan" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).

Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) reads the illegible word after "Leave us not in" as "Parsimony", while Erdman conjecturally reads the text as "Poverty and Want" (659). Bentley notes that the word he reads as "Parsimony" "looks in fact like ‘Persuasion’” (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).
Bentley omits "job" from his transcription (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516). Erdman reads "job" as "Jobs" (669).
Bentley reads the first character of the illegible text after "Natural Man" as an ampersand (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516). Erdman reads the illegible text after "Natural Man" as "& want" (669).

l.hi: for thine is the Kingdom & the P
r & the Glory & not Caesars or Satans Amen
l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (669) read "for" as "For".
Erdman reads a period after "Amen" (669).
This line is written vertically, starting in the lower right margin of the object. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (668) read this line as a continuation of the text on line 4.
Bentley reads a period after "The Accuser" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (668) read "hemay" as "he may".
Bentley conjecturally reads "consed" as "coverd" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516), while Erdman conjecturally reads the word as "consumd" (668).

Erdman reads "Common" as "common" (669). Bentley reads the text transcribed on lines 11 and 12 as "have all things Common All Things common among us". Within that reading, Bentley reads "all things" as an insertion and the subsequent "All Things common" with uncertainty (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516).

l.hi: has as much right to Eternal Life as God who is the Servant of Ma
l.note: Bentley reads "Evry thing" as "Every thing" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516), Erdman reads the text as "Every Thing" (669).
This line is written vertically, starting in the lower right margin of the object.
Erdman reads "The" as "His" (669).
This line is written vertically, starting in the lower right margin of the object.
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (669) read "Forgivness" as "Forgiveness".

lg.l: a Female God

objnote.p: Blake's inscription on this object is written vertically, starting in the lower right corner and following the right margin.

lg.l: So you See That God is just such a Tyrant as Augustus Ceasar Augustus Caesar & is not this GoodBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1516) and Erdman (669) read "Ceasar" as "Caesar".
& Learned & Wise & Classical

desc.objtitle:
Reasons For A New Translation of the Whole Bible. Page 9 ,
Object 9 (Bentley 9, Erdman 9)

lg.l: The only thing for Newtonian & Baconian Philosophers to Consider is this WhetherAn ink blot appears under the "N" in "Newtonian".
Jesus did not suffer himself to be Mocked by Caesars Caesar's Soldiers WillinglyBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) reads "Mocked" as "Mock'd", while Erdman reads the word as "Mockd" (669).
& I hope they will Consider this to all Eternity will be Comment EnoughBentley reads "Comment" as "comment" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517).

objnote.p: Blake's inscription on this object was originally written in pencil; two lines at the top of the page (lines 1-2) and six at the bottom (lines 30-36) are confirmed in black ink.

lg.l: This is Saying the Lords Prayer The Lord's Prayer Backwards
which they say Raises the devil Erdman reads "devil" as "Devil" (669).
its disguise in the ^ Scotch language into an EnglishBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) and Erdman (669) read the partially-illegible word after "into" as "plain".

l.hi: Our Father Augustus Caesar who art in this thy Heavens
l.note: Erdman reads "this" as "these" (669).
Bentley notes that the downstroke on the "s" in "Heavens" makes the letter appear as a "g" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517).

l.add: or Title & reverence to thy Shadow

l.hi: first & thence in Heaven Give us day by day our Real
l.note: Bentley reads "thence" as "then" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517).
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) reads the partially-illegible phrase starting with "call" as "can pay tax", while Erdman reads the phrase as "call Nature" (669).

l.add: deliver from the Holy Ghost^ ver cant be Taxed
l.note: Bentley reads "Money bought" in line with the text on line 14 (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517).
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) and Erdman (669) omit the period after "Money".
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) and Erdman (669) read the two mostly-illegible words on line 13 as "whatever cannot".
Bentley reads "Have" as "have" and reads the subsequent illegible word as "that" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517).

l.add: for all is debts & Taxes between Caesar & us & one anot
l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) and Erdman (669) read the mostly-illegible word on line 15 as "another".

l.add: lead us not to read the Bible
l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) and Erdman (669) read the illegible word after "owing to" as "him".
Bentley reads a period after "that Evil one" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517).

l.hi: us from Poverty in Jesus For thine
l.note: Bentley reads "Bible be Virgil & Shakspeare" in line with the text on line 16 (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517).
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) and Erdman (669) read the partially-illegible word on this line as "Kingship".
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1517) and Erdman (669) read the partially-illegible word on this line as "Power".

l.add: for God is only an Allegory of Kings & nothing Else
l.note: Erdman reads "descendants" as "Descendants" (669).

l.hi: I swear that Basileia Βασιλεια is not Kingdom
l.note: The Greek character "σ" (sigma) bears a resemblance to the form of the letter typically used in the final position.

l.hi: Spirit is the Ghost of Matter or Nature & God is
The Ghost of the Priest & King who Exist

lg.l: God exists not except from themir Effluvia Erdman conjecturally reads "them" beneath "their" (669).
Here is Signed Two Names which
are too Holy to be Written
Thus we see that the Real God is the Goddess Nature
& that God Creates nothing but what can be Touchd Touched & Weighed & TaxedLine 33 is confirmed in black ink.
& Measured all else is Heresy & Rebellion against Ceasiar Caesar Erdman reads "Ceasiar" as "Caesar" (670).

Virgils Only God See Eclogue i Eclogue 1 & for all this we Thank DrDoctor Thornton Bentley omits the ampersand after "Eclogue i" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1518). Erdman reads "Thank" as "thank" (670).

objnote.p: The inscription, not by Blake, on this object transcribes Blake's annotations on the previous page (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 1753).

l.hi: this is saying The Lords Prayer The Lord's Prayer Backwards
which they say Raises The Devil.
Doctor Thornton's Tory TranslationTranslated out of
its disguise in the classical & scotch languagesinto the vulgar English
l.note: An inkblot appears after the word "vulgar".

l.hi: Our Father Augustus Caesar who art in These thy Substantial astronomical

l.note: "Telescopic Heavens:" is underlined.

l.hi: Holiness to thy Name or title & reverence to thy shadow

l.note: "first & Then in Heaven" is underlined.

l.hi: Give us day by day our Real substantial Money bought Taxed Bread
deliver us from The Holy Ghost. . . . . . . . ._ . . . cannot be Taxed

l.note: A smudge, which may have originally been a letter or letters, appears at the beginning of this line.

l.hi: for all _ debts & Taxes between Ceasar Caesar & us & one another

hi.add: & deliver us from Poverty in Jesus.

l.hi: lead us not to read The Bible but let our Bïble be Virgil & ShakspeareShakespeare
For thine is the Kingship or Allegoric Godship,
& the Power, or War, & the Glory or Law Ages after Ages
in thy descendants' for God is only an Allegory of Kings & Nothing Else;

l.note: Part of the word "Amen" is underlined.

l.hi: I swear that Basileia Βασιλεια is not kingdom but kingship
